text: `Int <: Number`

```julia> Int <: Number
true```

```julia> Int <: String
false```

Just a word of advice: you'll learn more if you try things out by yourself in the Julia REPL first. Most examples in the Julia manual can be copied as is and run in the REPL. You just have to try them out.

text:
> it looks like supertype(Int64)==Number
Incorrect. `supertype(Int64)` is actually `Signed`, so `supertype(Int64)==Number` is actually `false`. `supertype()` gives you the direct supertype of a type. `<:` is about whether the type is a subtype of the type on the right, or one of its subtypes, recursively.

elements.text: gives you the direct supertype of a type.
is about whether the type is a subtype of the type on the right, or one of its subtypes, recursively.

Couldnt find anywhere where it says its a comparision operator

text: Its more like inheritance
Yes. You can use `<:` both in type definitions and to test a subtype relationship.

elements.text: both in type definitions and to test a subtype relationship.

In the docs

text:
The link doesn’t seem to scroll you to the right place, but you can search once there. Or online help:
```help?> <:
search: <:

  <:(T1, T2)

  Subtype operator: returns true if and only if all values of type T1 are also of type T2.

  Examples
  ≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡

  julia> Float64 <: AbstractFloat
  true
  
  julia> Vector{Int} <: AbstractArray
  true
  
  julia> Matrix{Float64} <: Matrix{AbstractFloat}
  false```

elements.text: The link doesn’t seem to scroll you to the right place, but you can search once there. Or online help:

help?> <:
search: <:

  <:(T1, T2)

  Subtype operator: returns true if and only if all values of type T1 are also of type T2.

  Examples
  ≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡

  julia> Float64 <: AbstractFloat
  true
  
  julia> Vector{Int} <: AbstractArray
  true
  
  julia> Matrix{Float64} <: Matrix{AbstractFloat}
  false

text: Indeed. Once again, you could just have used the Julia REPL and it would have given you the answer you were looking for.

text: What about Int64 isa Number isnt isa the same

elements.text: What about Int64 isa Number isnt isa the same

text: No, `isa` takes a _value_ on the left. `<:` takes a _type_ on the left.
So you do `1 isa Number`, but `Int <: Number`.

```help?> isa
search: isa isascii isapprox isabspath isassigned isabstracttype disable_sigint isnan ispath isvalid

  isa(x, type) -> Bool

  Determine whether x is of the given type. Can also be used as an infix operator, e.g. x isa
  type.

  Examples
  ≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡

  julia> isa(1, Int)
  true
  
  julia> isa(1, Matrix)
  false
  
  julia> isa(1, Char)
  false
  
  julia> isa(1, Number)
  true
  
  julia> 1 isa Number
  true```

  type.

  Examples
  ≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡

  julia> isa(1, Matrix)
